sen.j: 浮世絵（うきよえ）は、江戸時代に成立した絵画のジャンルである。
sen.e: Ukiyoe is a genre of the pictorial arts established in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「浮世絵」をはじめ、日本語をローマ字化して表現した日本事象用語は、全編を通じてすべて最初の文字を大文字に統一いたしました。
sen.e: Ukiyoe is a genre of the pictorial arts established during the Edo period.
Ukiyoe is a genre of the pictorial arts established during the Edo period.

sen.j: 「浮世」という言葉には「現代風」という意味もあり、当代の風俗を描く風俗画である。
sen.e: The word, "ukiyo" (this life) also means "modern" and Ukiyoe is Fuzokuga (pictures of manners and customs) which depicts the manners and customs of the day.
The word "ukiyo" (this life) also means "modern," and Ukiyoe is Fuzokuga (pictures of manners and customs), which depicts the manners and customs of the day.
The word "ukiyo" (this life) also means "modern," and Ukiyoe refers to Fuzokuga, in which paintings depicts the manners and customs of the day.
sen.cmt: 説明が重複するので、(pictures of manners and customs) という部分を削除し、修正しました。is→refers to

sen.j: 大和絵の流れを汲み、総合的絵画様式としての文化的背景を保つ一方で、人々の日常の生活や風物などを描いている。
sen.e: Ukiyoe is descended from Yamato-e painting (a traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes), and keeping the cultural background of the comprehensive pictorial art genre, it depicts people's everyday life and scenery.

Ukiyoe is descended from Yamato-e painting (a traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes), and consistent with the cultural background of the comprehensive pictorial art genre, it depicts scenes from people's everyday life.

while Ukiyoe is descended from Yamato-e painting (a traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes), and consistent with the cultural background of the comprehensive pictorial art genre; by contrast, it depicts scenes from people's everyday life and things.
sen.cmt: ”一方で”という部分、”風物など”を挿入して修正しました。

sen.j: 現在一般に浮世絵といえば、専ら多色刷りの木版画（錦絵）を想起される場合が多いが、肉筆画（肉筆浮世絵）なども含まれる。
sen.e: When it comes to Ukiyoe generally in these days, one is solely reminded of the multicolor woodblock print (Nishikie (colored woodblock print)) in many cases, but original drawing (Ukiyoe painting) and so on are also included.

Generally, when it comes to Ukiyoe today, one is solely reminded of the multicolor woodblock print (Nishikie (colored woodblock print)) in many cases, but original drawings (Ukiyoe paintings) and so on are also included.

Generally, when it comes to Ukiyoe today, one is solely reminded of the multicolor woodblock print (Nishikie [colored woodblock print]) in many cases, but original drawings (Nikuhitsu Ukiyoe [single copy paintings created by brush]) and so on are also included.
sen.cmt: (())→([ ]),肉筆浮世絵： Nikuhitsu Ukiyoe (single copy paintings created by brush) とし、修正しました。参考URL(http://www.guimet.fr/Masterpieces-from-the-Ota-Memorial)

sen.j: 浮世絵には肉筆画のものと木版画のものがある。
sen.e: Ukiyoe is divided into 2 categories, the original drawing and the woodblock print.
Ukiyoe is divided into two categories: the original drawing and the woodblock print.
Ukiyoe is divided into two categories: the original drawing and the woodblock print.

sen.j: 肉筆画は一点ものであり、名のある絵師によるものは高価となり、また作品数も限られていた。
sen.e: An original drawing was made out as only one piece of work, and drawings of prestigious Eshi painters were expensive, the number of works of which were limited.
An original drawing was created as a single piece of work, and drawings of prestigious Eshi painters were expensive because the numbers of works were limited.
An original drawing was created as a single piece of work, and drawings of prestigious Eshi painters were expensive, and also the numbers of works were limited.

sen.j: これに対して、木版画は版画であるために、同じ絵柄のものを多く刷り上げることができ安価で、江戸時代の一般大衆もたやすく求められた。
sen.e: On the contrary, the woodblock print, because it's printmaking, can make many prints of the same picture inexpensively, thus even the general public of the Edo period was able to buy easily.
Contrastingly, the woodblock print could generate many prints of the same picture inexpensively, so even the general public of the Edo period was easily able to obtain such works.

Contrastingly, the woodblock print benefited from the fact that as a print, the same picture could be inexpensively printed off many times, so even the general public of the Edo period was easily able to obtain such works.
sen.cmt: ”版画であるために”という部分を挿入し、修正しました。

sen.j: 浮世絵版画は大衆文化の一部であり、手に取って眺め愛玩された。
sen.e: The Ukiyoe woodblock print was a part of the popular culture, and prints were prized by being picked up and looked at.
The Ukiyoe woodblock print was a part of the popular culture, and prints were appreciated by being picked up and looked at.
The Ukiyoe woodblock print was a part of the popular culture, and prints were adored by being picked up and looked at.

sen.j: 現代の美術展等のように額に入れて遠目に眺めるものではなかった。
sen.e: They were not framed and looked at from a distance as we know it today at art exhibitions, etc.
They were not framed and looked at from a distance as we know it today at art exhibitions, etc.
They were not framed and looked at from a distance as we know it today at art exhibitions, etc.

sen.j: 草双紙や絵巻物、また瓦版（新聞）の挿絵の役割も果たした。
sen.e: They played a role of illustrations for Kusazoshi (Japanese chapbooks), Emakimono (an illustrated scroll) and kawaraban (commercial news-sheet of the Edo period).
They served as illustrations for Kusazoshi (Japanese chapter books), Emakimono (illustrated scrolls) and kawaraban (commercial news sheets of the Edo period).
They served as illustrations for Kusazoshi (Japanese chapter books), Emakimono (illustrated scrolls) and Kawaraban (commercial news sheets of the Edo period).

sen.j: 絵暦と呼ばれるカレンダーの制作も行われ、絵の中に数字を隠すなど様々な工夫を凝らしたものが作られた。
sen.e: Picture calendars called Egoyomi, which included works with diverse ideas like one with hidden numbers in the picture were produced,
Picture calendars called Egoyomi, which included works with diverse ideas, such as having hidden numbers in the pictures, were produced.
Picture calendars called Egoyomi, which included works with diverse ideas, such as having hidden numbers in the pictures, were produced.

sen.j: 江戸から国元への土産にも、その美しさと嵩の低さが喜ばれた。
sen.e: As home-coming gifts from Edo Ukiyoe were appreciated due to their beauty and small size.
As homecoming gifts from Edo, Ukiyoe were appreciated due to their beauty and small size.
As homecoming gifts from Edo, Ukiyoe were appreciated due to their beauty and small size.

sen.j: 玩具絵のように切り抜いて遊ぶものもある。
sen.e: There was a type used for clipping play like Omochae (toy pictures for children).
There was a type used for clipping play, like Omochae (toy pictures for children).
There was a type used for clipping play, like Omochae (toy pictures for children).

sen.j: はっきりした図柄と大胆な構図、影の表現を持たないこと等が表現上の特徴である。
sen.e: Ukiyoe is, relating to expressiveness, characterized by clear-cut design, daring pattern, shadowless expression, etc.
Ukiyoe is, in terms of expressiveness, characterized by clear-cut design, daring patterns, shadowless expression, etc.
Ukiyoe is, in terms of expressiveness, characterized by clear-cut design, daring patterns, shadowless expression, etc.

sen.j: 遠近法も取り入れられた。
sen.e: Perspective was also introduced.
Perspective was also introduced.
Perspective was also introduced.

sen.j: 遠景の人物を逆に大きく描く北斎の『釣の名人』のように、意図的に遠近をずらされたものもある。
sen.e: There was such a type in which perspective was intentionally ignored as Hokusai's "Tsuri no meijin" (Master of fishing) where a figure in the distance was conversely depicted as larger.
There was a type in which perspective was intentionally ignored, as demonstrated in Hokusai's "Tsuri no meijin" (Master of fishing), where a figure in the distance is conversely depicted as larger.

sen.j: もともと浮世絵は、浮世を描いた絵、風俗画として登場している。
sen.e: Ukiyoe originally appeared as pictures of manners and customs, which depict ukiyo (this life).
Ukiyoe originally appeared as pictures of manners and customs, thus depicting ukiyo (this life).
Ukiyoe originally appeared as paintings depicting the customs and manners of everyday life, 'ukiyo.'

sen.e: Early stages

sen.j: 明暦の大火から宝暦の頃。
sen.e: From the Great Fire in Meireki to around Houreki era
From the Great Fire in Meireki to around the Houreki era

sen.j: 初期の浮世絵は肉筆画と木版の単色刷り（墨摺絵）が主である。
sen.e: Ukiyoe in the early stages were mainly original drawings and single color printing of woodblock (Sumizurie (picture printed in all black India ink lines)).
Ukiyoe in the early stages mainly consisted of original drawings and single-color woodblock printing (Sumizurie (pictures printed in black India ink lines)).

sen.j: 墨摺絵に赤い顔料で着色した丹絵（たんえ）、紅絵（べにえ）、さらに紅絵に緑色など二、三色加えた紅摺絵（べにずりえ）が登場する。
sen.e: There appeared Tan-e and Benie which were types of Sumizurie in which hand painted areas of orange pigment, tan, or red pigment, beni, were added, and furthermore, Benizurie which was also a type of Sumizurie in which hand painted areas of red pigment and a few additional colors including green were added.

There appeared Tan-e and Benie, which were types of Sumizurie in which hand-painted areas of orange pigment, tan or red pigment (beni) were added; there was also Benizurie, another type of Sumizurie in which hand-painted areas of red pigment and a few additional colors, such as green, were added.
There appeared Tan-e and Benie, which colored Sumizurie with red pigment; there was also Benizurie, in which adding few additional colors, such as green on Benie.
sen.cmt: 原文より、全体的に簡潔に修正しました。

sen.j: 錦絵登場の直前、輪郭線すらも墨を用いず「ツユクサ」の青色としたみずえ（みずえ）と呼ばれる、極端に彩度の低い多色刷りも生まれている。
sen.e: Immediately before appearance of Nishikie, an extremely low chromatic multicolor printing called Mizue where profile lines are drawn by "Tsuyukusa" (blue Asiatic Dayflower) rather than India ink was created.

sen.j: 鮮やかな多色刷りの東錦絵（吾妻錦絵）が編み出され、浮世絵文化が開花する。
sen.e: A bright multicolor printing, Azuma-nishikie (brocade picture of the East) was worked out, which made the Ukiyoe culture come into bloom.
A form of bright multicolor printing, Azuma-nishikie (brocade picture of the East) was devised, and it brought the Ukiyoe culture into bloom.

sen.j: 下絵師、彫師、刷師の分業体制が整っていく。
sen.e: The division of labor was beginning to be established among Shitaeshi (Ukiyoe artist), Horishi (carver) and Surishi (printer).

sen.e: Bijinga (a type of Ukiyoe portraying beautiful women), Yakushae (print of a Kabuki actor), Mushae (Ukiyoe prints of warriors) and along with travel boom, Meishoe (landscape drawing) were developed.

sen.j: 幕末から明治にかけて、横浜絵、開化絵、錦絵新聞など、西洋の事物や日本の世情紹介に浮世絵が大きな役割を果たす。
sen.e: From the end of Edo period down to the Meiji period, such Ukiyoe as Yokohama-e (Yokohama Ukiyoe), Kaikae (Enlightenment Ukiyoe), Nishikie-shinbun (newspaper) and so on played an important role in introducing things Western and the Japanese situation.

sen.e: From the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period, such Ukiyoe as Yokohama-e (Yokohama Ukiyoe), Kaikae (Enlightenment Ukiyoe), Nishikie-shinbun (newspapers) and so on played an important role in introducing things Western as well as the Japanese situation.

sen.j: 戦乱を反映した無残絵、戦争絵も歓迎されたが、やがて浮世絵は、新聞、写真など他のメディアに押されて衰退していく。
sen.e: Muzan-e (atrocity print) and Sensou-e (prints of war/battle scenes) which reflected scenes of war were well received, but Ukiyoe eventually headed for decline, losing ground to such other media as newspapers, photographs, etc.

Muzan-e (atrocity prints) and Sensou-e (prints of war, or battle scenes), were well received, but Ukiyoe eventually began to decline, losing ground to other media such as newspapers, photographs, etc.
Muzan-e (atrocity prints) and Senso-e (prints of war, or battle scenes), were well received, but Ukiyoe eventually began to decline, losing ground to other media such as newspapers, photographs, etc.

sen.j: 絵師は挿絵画家や日本画家に転じ、浮世絵の伝統は他のジャンルへと受け継がれていった。
sen.e: Eshi painters changed their career to become illustrators and Japanese-style painters, and the tradition of Ukiyoe came down to other genres.
Eshi painters changed careers and became illustrators and Japanese-style painters, and the tradition of Ukiyoe came down to other genres.

sen.j: 明暦の大火ごろから宝暦の頃までをさす。

sen.j: 初期の浮世絵は肉筆画と木版の単色刷り（墨摺絵）が主である。

sen.j: 17世紀半ば以降、木版画の原図を描く者を版下絵師といい、その中で絵本や浮世草子に挿絵を描いた菱川師宣が登場する。
sen.e: After the mid-17th century, a person who made original drawings for woodblock prints was called Hanshita-eshi (professional draftman), then Moronobu HISHIKAWA who drew illustrations for picture books and Ukiyo-zoshi (popular stories of everyday life in the Edo period) made his appearance.
sen.cmt: 「浮世草子」の訳の括弧内の説明(popular stories of everyday life in the Edo period)は、[研究社 新和英大辞典第５版]から取りました。
sen.e: After the mid-seventeenth century, a person who made original drawings for woodblock prints was called Hanshita-eshi (professional draftsman), then Moronobu HISHIKAWA, who drew illustrations for picture books and Ukiyo-zoshi (popular stories of everyday life in the Edo period), made his appearance.

After the mid-17th century, a person who made original drawings for woodblock prints was called Hanshita-eshi (professional draftsman), then Moronobu HISHIKAWA, who drew illustrations for picture books and Ukiyo-zoshi (popular stories of everyday life in the Edo period), made his appearance.
sen.cmt: seventeenth→17th （”10 以上 アラビア数字で表記”という統一事項に従いました）

sen.j: また、代表作として有名な『見返り美人図』は肉筆画である。
sen.e: The famous "Mikaeri Bijin zu" (Picture of looking-back beauty) which is the most important work of him is an original drawing.
sen.cmt: 『見返り美人図』は、独断で訳しました。

sen.j: 西鶴の『好色一代男』（1682年刊）には、12本骨の扇子に浮世絵が描かれていたとあり、これが浮世絵という言葉の確認出来る最古の文献である。
sen.e: Saikaku's "Koshoku ichidai otoko" (Life of a Sensuous Man) (published in 1682) describes that Ukiyoe was drawn on a folding fan with 12 ribs, and this is the oldest literature in which the word of Ukiyoe can be found.
sen.cmt: 「好色一代男」は、日本語用語をローマ字化して記載しました。
sen.e: Saikaku's "Koshoku ichidai otoko (Life of a Sensuous Man)" (published in 1682) describes that Ukiyoe was drawn on a folding fan with 12 ribs, and this is the oldest literature in which the word "Ukiyoe" can be found.

Saikaku's "Koshoku ichidai otoko (Life of a Amorous Man)" (published in 1682) describes that Ukiyoe was drawn on a folding fan with 12 ribs, and this is the oldest literature in which the word "Ukiyoe" can be found.

sen.j: 鳥居清信の時代になると墨摺絵に筆で着色したものが現れる。
sen.e: After the days of Kiyonobu TORII began, there appeared a type of Sumizurie colored by ink brush.
After the days of Kiyonobu TORII began, there appeared a type of Sumizurie colored with ink brush.

sen.j: これらは主に赤い顔料を使い着色され、丹を使ったものを丹絵（たんえ）、紅を使ったものを紅絵（べにえ）と呼んだ。
sen.e: These were colored mainly with red pigments and one with tan being used was called Tan-e and one with beni was called Benie.

sen.j: さらに紅絵に色を二、三色加えたものを紅摺絵（べにずりえ）と呼ぶ。

sen.j: この当時から鳥居派は歌舞伎と強く結びつき、現代でも歌舞伎の看板を手がけている。
sen.e: From back then, Torii school of Ukiyoe has closely been associated with Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) and works on Kabuki billboards even today.

sen.j: 錦絵が誕生した明和2年から文化3年頃をさす。

sen.j: 1765年（明和2年）に江戸の俳人を中心に絵暦が流行し、絵暦交換会が開かれるようになった。
sen.e: In 1765, Egoyomi (picture calendars) became fashionable especially among Haiku poets and Egoyomi exchange party came to be held.

sen.j: その需要に伴い鈴木春信らが多色刷りによる東錦絵（吾妻錦絵）を編み出したことで、浮世絵文化は本格的開花期を迎えた。
sen.e: To meet the demand, Harunobu SUZUKI and others worked out Azuma-nishikie printed in multicolor and Ukiyoe culture came into the full-scale blooming stage.
To meet the demand, Harunobu SUZUKI and others worked out Azuma-nishikie printed in multiple colors, and the Ukiyoe culture came into full bloom.

sen.j: 多色刷りが可能になった背景には、重ね刷りの際の目印となるよう「見当」が工夫されたこと、複数回の刷りに耐えられる丈夫で高品質な和紙が普及したことが挙げられる。
sen.e: As background factors of why the multicolor printing was made possible, it is pointed out that "Kentou" (guide marks) was introduced to mark the point for overprinting and that strong, high-quality Japanese papers which absorbed multiple printing became available.

As to the factors by which multicolor printing was made possible, it is pointed out that "Kentou" (guide marks) were introduced to mark the points for overprinting, and that strong, high-quality Japanese papers that absorbed multiple-color printing became available.

As to the factors by which multicolor printing was made possible, it is pointed out that "Kento" (guide marks) were introduced to mark the points for overprinting, and that strong, high-quality Japanese papers that withstood multiple-color printing became available.

sen.e: While in Japan which was domestically disrupted by Meiji Restoration, grotesque things appeared in Kabuki and shows, Yoshiiku OCHIAI and Yoshitoshi TSUKIOKA who were disciples of Kuniyoshi UTAGAWA drew "Eimei nijuhatishuku" which depicted bloody scenes and were called Muzan-e and also illustrations for articles on Nishikie-shinbun.

sen.e: While in Japan which was domestically disrupted by the Meiji Restoration, grotesque things appeared in Kabuki and other shows, Yoshiiku OCHIAI and Yoshitoshi TSUKIOKA, who were disciples of Kuniyoshi UTAGAWA, drew "Eimei nijuhatishuku," which depicted bloody scenes and were called Muzan-e, as well as illustrations for articles in Nishikie-shinbun.

sen.j: 月岡芳年は繊細で写生を重視した絵柄で無惨絵ばかりでなく数多くの歴史画、風俗画をてがけ、「最後の浮世絵師」と呼ばれるようになる。

sen.e: Ukiyoe even influenced classical music, as Claude Debussy was inspired by Hokusai's "Kanagawa oki nami ura (Behind the Great Wave at Kanagawa)" and composed "La Mer (The Sea)"(the print was used on the front cover of the full score published in 1905, and there is a photograph in which the print can be identified as an ornament in a study).

Ukiyoe even influenced classical music, as Claude DEBUSSY was inspired by Hokusai's "Kanagawa oki nami ura (Behind the Great Wave at Kanagawa)" and composed "La Mer (The Sea)"(the print was used on the front cover of the full score published in 1905, and there is a photograph in which the print can be identified as an ornament in a study).
